snippet: While the new use removes blight, restores health care services and creates jobs, critics worry these facilities are no substitute for the hospitals they’ve replaced.
abstract: New Jersey developers have been buying up shuttered hospitals and reopening them as private medical complexes; trend has reduced blight, created jobs and restored much-needed local services as hospitals shut down, but critics worry that they do not provide same level of care; private complexes do not have nonprofit community missions and are able to refuse service to those who cannot afford it.
lead_paragraph: While the new use removes blight, restores health care services and creates jobs, critics worry these facilities are no substitute for the hospitals they’ve replaced.

headline.main: Repurposing Closed Hospitals as For-Profit Medical Malls
headline.print_headline: Repurposing Closed Hospitals as For-Profit Medical Malls
